[[Richard_William_Paul|Richard William Paul]] and Linda Elder {{Who|date=June 2014}} define ethics as "a set of concepts and principles that guide us in determining what behavior helps or harms sentient creatures".<ref name="ReferenceA"/>{{Relevance-inline|date=June 2014}}<br>
 
The ''[[Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy]]'' states that the word ethics is "commonly used interchangeably with '[[morality]]' ... and sometimes it is used more narrowly to mean the moral principles of a particular tradition, group or individual."<ref>John Deigh in Robert Audi (ed), ''The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy'', 1995.</ref>{{Clarify|reason= Add the full quote}} Paul states that most people confuse ethics with behaving in accordance with social conventions, religious beliefs and the law and don't treat ethics as a stand-alone concept.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |title= The Miniature Guide to Understanding the Foundations of Ethical Reasoning|edition= |last1= Paul|first1= Richard|last2= Elder|first2= Linda|year= 2006|publisher= Foundation for Critical Thinking Free Press|location= United States|isbn= 0-944583-17-2|page= np}}</ref>
